question.title: NoClassDefFoundError when running Jersey in GAE

node.contents: I am trying to expose a web service using Jersey in GAE.

astNode.text: I am trying to expose a web service using Jersey in GAE.

elements.contents: [INFO] java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: sun.misc.Unsafe is a restricted class. Please see the Google App Engine developer's guide for more details. [INFO] at com.google.appengine.tools.development.agent.runtime.Runtime.reject(Runtime.java:51) [INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.ConcurrentHashMapV8.getUnsafe(ConcurrentHashMapV8.java:3502) [INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.ConcurrentHashMapV8.<clinit>(ConcurrentHashMapV8.java:3467) [INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.DataStructures.createConcurrentMap(DataStructures.java:237) [INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.message.internal.MessageBodyFactory.<init>(MessageBodyFactory.java:197)

fragments.text: is a restricted class. Please see the Google App Engine developer's guide for more details. [INFO]

units.rawText: [INFO] java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: sun.misc.Unsafe is a restricted class. Please see the Google App Engine developer's guide for more details. [INFO] at com.google.appengine.tools.development.agent.runtime.Runtime.reject(Runtime.java:51)[INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.ConcurrentHashMapV8.getUnsafe(ConcurrentHashMapV8.java:3502)[INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.ConcurrentHashMapV8.<clinit>(ConcurrentHashMapV8.java:3467)[INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.util.collection.DataStructures.createConcurrentMap(DataStructures.java:237)[INFO] at org.glassfish.jersey.message.internal.MessageBodyFactory.<init>(MessageBodyFactory.java:197)

node.contents: Is this a known issue? If so, is there a workaround?

astNode.text: Is this a known issue? If so, is there a workaround?

node.contents: I am using Maven and used the following dependency to add Jersey to the project

astNode.text: I am using Maven and used the following dependency to add Jersey to the project

node.contents: Following is the part from my web.xml where I configured Jersey:

astNode.text: Following is the part from my web.xml where I configured Jersey:

node.contents: java.misc.Unsafe is not available in the Java runtime on App Engine.

astNode.text: java.misc.Unsafe is not available in the Java runtime on App Engine.

node.contents: You should add java.misc.Unsafe to the lib folder of the web application so that it is available at runtime.

astNode.text: You should add java.misc.Unsafe to the lib folder of the web application so that it is available at runtime.

node.contents: Alternatively I suggest you to use NetBeans or any other IDE and create a REST service from there, it will automatically configure needed libraries and add them for you to the library folder.

astNode.text: Alternatively I suggest you to use NetBeans or any other IDE and create a REST service from there, it will automatically configure needed libraries and add them for you to the library folder.

node.contents: As last, check that you're using the correct JVM when compiling and when deploying.

astNode.text: As last, check that you're using the correct JVM when compiling and when deploying.

node.contents: I just ran into the same issue: Everything works locally with jersey 2.3.1 and breaks on appengine due to the sun.misc.Unsafe class. I didn't want to go back to older jersey Versions, so I checked the jersey-source to maybe find a patch for this. I found out, that they actually select the ConcurrentMap-implementation based on the flag JdkVersion.IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED resulting in either ConcurrentHashMap (when unsupprted) or ConcurrentHashMapV8 (when supported). So I patched the class JdkVersion by removing

astNode.text: I just ran into the same issue: Everything works locally with jersey 2.3.1 and breaks on appengine due to the sun.misc.Unsafe class. I didn't want to go back to older jersey Versions, so I checked the jersey-source to maybe find a patch for this. I found out, that they actually select the ConcurrentMap-implementation based on the flag JdkVersion.IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED resulting in either ConcurrentHashMap (when unsupprted) or ConcurrentHashMapV8 (when supported). So I patched the class JdkVersion by removing

elements.contents: static { boolean isUnsafeFound; try { isUnsafeFound = Class.forName("sun.misc.Unsafe") != null; } catch (Throwable t) { isUnsafeFound = false; } IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED = isUnsafeFound; }

units.rawText: static { boolean isUnsafeFound; try { isUnsafeFound = Class.forName("sun.misc.Unsafe") != null; } catch (Throwable t) { isUnsafeFound = false; } IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED = isUnsafeFound; }

elements.contents: private static final boolean IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED = false;

units.rawText: private static final boolean IS_UNSAFE_SUPPORTED = false;

node.contents: With this my app works fine with jersey 2.3.1 on appengine ;)

astNode.text: With this my app works fine with jersey 2.3.1 on appengine ;)

node.contents: You will need to use an older version of Jersey as version 2 is not compatible with GAE.

astNode.text: You will need to use an older version of Jersey as version 2 is not compatible with GAE.

node.contents: Version 1.5 is listed by Google as being compatible: https://code.google.com/p/googleappengine/wiki/WillItPlayInJava

astNode.text: Version 1.5 is listed by Google as being compatible: https://code.google.com/p/googleappengine/wiki/WillItPlayInJava
